Datatable.LocalizationPair: Insufficient Excess Food.
Enable Food Rework

Determines whether the ESG Food rework will be enabled. If partially enabled, there will be new empire improvements to convert excess food into other resources. If fully enabled, then population growth will be uncapped by a constructible element
Conversion + Uncapped
You will use ESG food. There will be options to convert excess food into other resources and additional population.
Conversion Only
You will partially use ESG food. There will be options to convert excess food into other resources, but not into additional population.
False
You will use Vanilla food. Excess food will be wasted, and only 1 population can grow per turn.
Population Cloning
Using innovative technologies alongside food surplus it is possible to create population, albeit at an extra cost.
Population Cloning
Using innovative technologies alongside food surplus it is possible to create population, albeit at an extra cost.

The Garrison represents the ability of the system to repel ground invasions. The [systemDefenseColored] Garrison Manpower and [foodColored] Food Conversion gradually restore this value, while enemy sieges and ground battle losses reduce it. Excess [systemDefenseColored] Manpower is sent to the [manpowerColored] Empire Manpower stock.

Effects
Applicable Efficiencies

Due to the similarities between many extractive ventures, a bit of Dust and some study in one field has quickly extended to many others, allowing the Hero to maximize production of both the finest luxuries and the most volatile strategic resources.

This is an agreement to share faction advantages with the Sophon. Your faction will gain +0.83% [scienceColored] on Systems per Turn [turn] (Max: 25%), increase scales with game speed.

A science bonus is given for discovering technologies based on how many players have already researched it: the fewer know it, the higher the reduction on the next research.
Starting Ships: 1x [colonizer], 1x [explorer] Faction Pact: +0.83% [scienceColored] per [turn] (Max: 25%)
This is an agreement to share faction advantages with the Riftborn. Your faction will gain +0.67% [industryColored] on Systems per Turn [turn] (Max: 20%), increase scales with game speed.

Can build Singularities, and affect time by placing them on a system. Singularities have a fixed duration and can only be placed on a system within the empire's vision
Starting Ships: 1x [colonizer], 1x [explorer] Faction Pact: +0.67% [industryColored] per [turn] (Max: 20%)
-2 [happinessColored] per [population] on Planets with Temples
Scrupulous Scientific Examination of Cultural Artifacts

The relics of the past are a thing to be studied using the scientific method! By providing research institutions the ability to get their hands on our relics, we will be ushering in an age known only to our ancestors! Our believers may protest the sacrilege of converting their places of worships into a science fair, but one must make way for progress.
Research Reliquaries Act
Temples
Imprint Analyzers Foundation

The relics of our past have been through a millenia of history using newfound methods of Dust-9 dating. By performing careful scans, we can get a clearer understanding of what the microscopic traces of dust on each relic have been through, and of course of our unrecorded history.
Enhanced Argosy Hull
Mobile Wormhole Concentrators
Allows the Argosy to consume all Movement Points to act as a Mobile Portal Argosy can Cloak Fleets at Level 1 without Modules
Portal use costs only 1 Movement Point (Bonus also applies to allies with the Metafolding Affinity)
Xenobiological Incentives

Divided between cold and disinterested masters and their slaves, Craver society can offer few incentives to its denizens. However, by exploiting luxuries as a reward for collaborators and additives for the main Craver population, a profitable system of incentives can still be achieved.
Alternative Food Programs

Both Cravers and their victims long ago realized that eating the labor force was not a good long term plan, and so food growing programs were created to take advantage of a planets natural biosphere for more efficient and sustainable fueling of the war machine.
Expendable Dust Expertise

Dust-empowered individuals are few and far between, but not too difficult to find during the food conversion process. By removing both Craver and conquered from the population when these talents show themselves, we can maintain an elite Dust labor force who shall live short, but significantly more pleasant lives until the construction efforts burn them out.
Conquest Announcement Networks

Cravers and their slaves derive little joy from the empires progress, but by hooking the former into a mental network and giving the latter constant updates from screens and speakers, every achievement can heighten the excitement of the Cravers and beat down the hope of their victims in real-time.
Body Language Programming

By obtaining other factions guides to diplomacy and facial recognition databases, we can create Craver specialists programmed to identify and exploit not only the emotional responses of other factions, but also of conquered populations who might be more amenable to the carrot or the stick at any moment.
Evolutionary Analysis Pens

One of the limits of natural evolution is that it cannot handle large changes well, as species are wiped out by disasters or predators which are too great a difference for them - Predators like the Cravers. By setting aside entire continents to only ever be attacked by Craver scouts and raiding parties that they can just about handle, we can observe our own weaknesses in an arena where our economy of scale will not obscure the results.
Intergalactic Hostages

By establishing "foreign exchange" arrangements with allies and offering hits of Dust-9 to famous figures in other empires, the Cravers can offer significant incentives to foreign politicians as an incentive to collaborate, and the threat of punishing famous prisoners and entire populations of their distant relatives as a convenient threat to prevent war without ruining the reputation of said politicians at home.
Hazardous Mining Hives

Through intense experimentation, we have created an offshoot of the Craver species whose birth is caused by the chemical triggers of valuable strategic resources. Cheap, tough, and tireless, these worker drone hives are well suited to the most dangerous of environments.
Collaborative Research Academies

While it is dangerous to allow educated members of the empire and its victims such unrestricted access to one another, giving scientists and their families exemption from hard labor in return for working with Craver scientists can prove a boon, especially when provided with expendable Craver assistants which will not complain about radiation or experimentation.
Dust-Consuming Collectors

By putting a new variety of cheap, expendable Dust-consuming Cravers under the command of regular Cravers with a mastery of Dust, we can mine vast amounts of it at extremely low cost using these self-sustaining mini-hives of hungerless workers and clairvoyant overseers.
Aerial Drone Deployments

Cravers are a heavy species, not least due to being cyborgs, and that can make life on a gas giant more difficult. While they are no longer recognizable as Cravers and make the rest of their species uncomfortable, prefab hives of dormant aerial drones can be deployed to harvest and explore these worlds as though they were native to the environment.

Anti-Radiation Campuses

While the Sophons are generally are interested in using the most cutting edge technology in the development of their labs with the expectation that advanced tools will beget more advanced tech, in the matter of laboratory radiation shielding they are traditionalists, constructing sprawling underground campuses modeled off of the steam cave communities of Hekim to accommodate entire towns of researchers and their families.
Hadeo-Industrial Infrastructure

There's a time and place for everything, but the time and place for metallurgy is immediately and on the hottest planets we can find. By setting up industrial-scale forges on planets already hot enough to melt metal using only its hellish atmospheric forces, industrial manufacturing can run at breakneck speeds. While there are small inefficiencies with the materials the factories are made out of melting, the gains far outweight the costs.
Glacial-Sanitization Laboratories

While sanitization is always important when studying biology, advances in xenobiology have uncovered new ways of perfectly sterilizing equipment to reduce any chance of contamination. The downside? This only works on planets with temperatures far below most would consider habitable, but the research applications are too good to ignore.

Can accumulate Keii and use it to launch Keii actions to boost the military and production capacities of systems. Keii also determines empire and system Obedience, which replaces Approval. +40% [honorColored] Keii from Space Battles under the Keii zone of Behemoths.

Cannot build Colonizers, but instead Vineships, which are used to extend your Vines to adjacent systems. Uncolonized systems in the vine network are colonized instantly. Planets in colonized systems require no industry to colonize. Can only engage in Diplomacy with Minor Factions in the Vine Network Vined systems are granted the following: • +10% [foodColored] • +10 [happinessColored] • -20% Siege Manpower Damage +1000 [systemDefenseColored] Garrison Capacity on Capital

Alliances
Determines how alliances will be treated.
Disabled
Alliances will be unable to be formed.
Standard
Alliances will function normally, and no pre-decided teams will be enforced.
Forced: 2 Teams

Two teams will automatically be created based off of the following rule: Team 1: Players 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, and 11 Team 2: Players 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, and 12 [red]Forced Alliances cannot receive or lose members#REVERT#
Forced: 3 Teams

Three teams will automatically be created based off of the following rule: Team 1: Players 1, 4, 7, and 10 Team 2: Players 2, 5, 8, and 11 Team 3: Players 3, 6, 9, and 12 [red]Forced Alliances cannot receive or lose members#REVERT#
Forced: 4 Teams

Four teams will automatically be created based off of the following rule: Team 1: Players 1, 5, and 9 Team 2: Players 2, 6, and 10 Team 3: Players 3, 7, and 11 Team 4: Players 4, 8 and 12 [red]Forced Alliances cannot receive or lose members#REVERT#
Forced: 6 Teams

Six teams will automatically be created based off of the following rule: Team 1: Players 1 and 7 Team 2: Players 2 and 8 Team 3: Players 3 and 9 Team 4: Players 4 and 10 Team 5: Players 5 and 11 Team 6: Players 6 and 12 [red]Forced Alliances cannot receive or lose members#REVERT#

The total Approval of your empire, calculated as an average of star system Approval ratings weighted by population. High and low approval values can influence the [scienceColored] and [dustColored] outputs of your star systems.
#4FC84F#Devoted#REVERT# - 85-100+ [happinessColored] (+30% [scienceColored] & [dustColored]) #B4C84F#Loyal#REVERT# - 70-85 [happinessColored] (+15% [scienceColored] & [dustColored]) #E1E1E1#Content#REVERT# - 30-70 [happinessColored] (No effects) #E1D768#Defiant#REVERT# - 15-30 [happinessColored] (-15% [scienceColored] & [dustColored]) #C84F4F#Traitorous#REVERT#: 0-15 [happinessColored] (-30% [scienceColored] & [dustColored])

Resource Generation on Strategic Resource Deposit
Insulated Government
The political bodies of the faction are not designed to change quickly, or even at all, so their reforms are constantly at risk of returning to the traditional status quo without immense support.
Micro-Military Teleporters

"Micro" may be an exaggeration, but for how long range these teleporters are, they do transport very little - specifically, the new sailors and marines necessary to crew the empires most distant starships, sent on a one-way trip to distant stars where they may complain far, far away from the people who sent them.

Displays the chance that civilian Population will be killed using this Tactic. Negative numbers mean population are less likely to be killed, and positive numbers mean population are more likely to be killed.

Displays the chance that System Improvements will be destroyed using this Tactic. Negative numbers mean improvements are less likely to be destroyed, and positive numbers mean improvements are more likely to be destroyed.
400-800 Offensive Bombardment Damage
800-1200 Offensive Bombardment Damage
1500-2000 Defensive Bombardment Damage
Masters of the Arena

The sun beats down, sweltering, and sweat prickles your brow. The noisy bloodlust of the crowd together with the dry dust churned up by the combatants, suffocates too. For a dizzying moment, you wonder what possessed you to accept the $MinorFactionName leader's invitation to their bloodsports arena, but then you remember: you court their civilization, and hope these are necessary steps towards the $MinorFactionName's assimilation into your empire. Far below, a fighter in golden scale neatly rolls to one side through the sand, and impales the last of the tri-headed mechanical snakes. The beast slumps to the ground, electricity crackling over its metallic form, and the crowd roars their approval. The leader leans close, its smell powerful and unpleasant. "That's my Finance Minister. He lives and breathes economics--but first and foremost, he's a warrior." The $MinorFactionName lowers its voice. "Show me your passion for violence, and you will have our loyalty,"
Demonstrating your civilization's militarism shouldn't be too difficult--you just hope you don't have to go to war to prove your colors.
Construct $Amount01Name [systemDefenseColored] improvements in your Empire

The $MinorFactionName leader sends their congratulations upon learning of the swell towards militarism across your Empire. The $MinorFactionName are now happy to join your empire.

Raid
Troops will prioritize causing economic devastation to the system, allowing your troop to focus on destroying things without regard for their well-being.
Rally

Your remaining troops will be concentrated in remaining military bases. While the clustered troops will be more likely to sustain injuries in sustained combat, the advantage of defensive artillery can not be ignored.
Diffusion Compensation Bombardment
Atmospheric diffusion limits the effectiveness of ionic plasma beams as an orbital bombardment weapon, but overwhelming directed energy can compensate for other shortcomings.
+750 Offensive Bombardment Damage on Preemptive Bombardment Nakalim [Templar] - +1000 Offensive Bombardment Damage on Precision A2G Strikes
Precision Shaped Bombardment
Techniques for the precision shaping of plasma blasts allows for the application of aerodynamic principles to orbital bombardment weaponry.
+750 Offensive Bombardment Damage on Preemptive Bombardment Nakalim [Templar] - +1000 Offensive Bombardment Damage on Precision A2G Strikes
Distributed-AI Patterned Bombardment
Allowing interested hobbyists access to military-spec orbital bombardment algorithms has resulted in a distributed computing network of AI-crafted bombardment patterns custom-fit to enemy defenses.
+750 Offensive Bombardment Damage on Preemptive Bombardment Nakalim [Templar] - +1000 Offensive Bombardment Damage on Precision A2G Strikes
Utopian Propaganda

Architecture and ship-building have long been the grandest, most difficult form of propaganda; but this faction has perfected the practice, constantly reminding people by whose godlike command the landscape changes and the skyline shifts, physically building the state-approved vision of the future.
Vault

The Vaulters picked up some idiosyncracies from their time on Auriga, with its brutal winters, tectonic instability, and murderous wildlife. Vast underground vaults, such as this one, allow individual Vaulter clans to stockpile their resources, insuring them against catastrophe - but providing a tempting target to invaders.
Invaders who Pillage this System will receive a hefty sum of Strategics, Science, and Dust Pillaging this System will not provide an Approval [happinessColored] malus for any Invaders

Every Colony can build a Portal that permits instantaneous travel to any other gate in the empire. Ships will automatically use gates to plot the most efficient route between any two Systems. Raiding your Systems will provide your enemies with an abundance of resources, and they will not suffer approval penalties.

Balance Home System Generation
Enabling this will guarantee an average starting Home System
True

False
Each faction will start with a randomly generated Home System.

This will determine the baseline colonization cap before incurring penalties for all empires.
If you are playing on a galaxy size with the recommended number of players, keeping this setting on 6 is advised. However, if you are playing with more or less players than recommendeded, it is advised that you adjust this setting accordingly.
The number of nodes per player on each galaxy size is the same, meaning a colonization cap of 6 will balancedly scale as long as you are using the recommended number of players.

Classified Corozian Theoretical Design Program

Though a dangerous process, it is just barely possible to communicate the needs of ship designs back to Coroz, where designers can slowly create ship designs with raw mathematical purity unachievable with the imprecise tools of a chaotic physical universe. The results are as terrifying as they were painstaking, built with perfect precision to strike out at an imperfect realm.
Theoretical Shipyards Bill
Jovial Work Ethic
Maximum [branch] Trade Subsidiaries
Stay Ahead Act
Bill #2956: Act for the Dissolution of Unnecessary Branches of the Legislative Organization for Preemptive Moral Victory in the face of Existential Threat and Enemy Incursion

It has come to our attention that there is something deeply wrong with the galaxy. We have tried to fight it, our ideological enemies and the threats presented by nature. We have done our best, and yet the universe continues to cruelly deny our righteousness! Because we have allowed ourselves to be corrupted, to fall to revision and reform. And according to our statistical research, it was inevitable.
The time has come to purify our ideology from the influence of foreign powers, so that we may be remembered according to our great feats, and not the corruption of our successors! Never again shall our beliefs be placed under threat by outsiders, nor by internal collaborators. History will remember us forever for what we do here today, an act of utmost humility for the good of our glorious state and ideology.
Thus I propose to you, the governing body of the empire, that we recognize our position at the zenith of history, and enact the discussed bill as-is, so we may all go home and enjoy this evening and many more, safe and comfortable in the knowledge that we have forever protected our beliefs from all further change.
To the Ideological Zenith! To our Glorious State! And to Retirement!
Eliminates your Empire
Force Trade Agreement

Force the another empire into a Trade Agreement, a Trade Agreement will trace routes between all your HQs and the other player's Subsidiaries, and vice versa. Trade Routes cannot cross enemy systems and can be interrupted by war, blockades, etc. Upkeep per Turn: 50 [prestigeColored]
Force Science Agreement

Force the another empire into a Science Agreement, where both you and the other player gain an incremental boost to your research; the longer the Science agreement lasts, the better the boost. Upkeep per Turn: 50 [prestigeColored]
Dust Memory Tracing

While it's always been known that Dust gets into our minds in order to enable such miraculous abilities for the lucky few, it's always been uncertain whether we could do the reverse and get into the mind of Dust. Until now, that is - through a combination of trained specialists and new financial modeling software, we can now read Dust to trace its journey through the universe and guide our security teams towards their quarry.
+50% Trace [hackingSpeed] Speed on Systems with Trade Company Headquarters
+15% Trace [hackingSpeed] Speed on Systems with Trade Company Subsidiaries
Mutual Agreements

With a better understanding of galactic-scale economics and the weird, wonderful, and often frankly upsetting ways that other species do business, our empire is finally positioned to establish trade treaties or research sharing agreements with other spacefaring empires.
Allows you to sign Trade Agreements and Science Agreements
Strongarm Economics

An unscrupulous government can get away with some astonishing things in the name of "Galactic Security". This legal framework allows for interventions in the nominally-private markets and scientific communities of other empires, strongarming their corporations into signing "mutually beneficial agreements".
Allows you to force Trade Agreements and Science Agreements Forced Agreements require the [pacifistColored] #a555e7#Pacifists#REVERT# to be the Primary Political Party
Forced Agreements require the [pacifistColored] #a555e7#Pacifists#REVERT# to be the Primary Political Party
Allows you to create/join an Alliance and exchange all Resources.
Allows you to create/join an Alliance and exchange all resources and technologies.
Forced Agreements require Pacifists to be the Primary Political Party
You need to build a Trade Company before you can propose a Trade Agreement
They need to build a Trade Company before you can propose a Trade Agreement
Both you and the other player gain an incremental boost to your research; the longer the Science agreement lasts, the better the boost. Upkeep per Turn: 50 [prestigeColored]

If signed, a Trade Agreement will trace routes between all your HQs and the other player's Subsidiaries, and vice versa. Trade Routes cannot cross enemy systems and can be interrupted by war, blockades, etc. Upkeep per Turn: 50 [prestigeColored]
This is a request to share the Ship, System and Probe Vision with another empire (you will see what they see on the galaxy view). Upkeep per Turn: 50 [prestigeColored]

Through a series of comforting talks and inconsequential promises, you manage to make it clear that you wish nothing more than to establish a peaceful relationship. Effects: -50% Peaceful Treaty [prestigecolored] Cost for 10 [turn] +100% Hostile Treaty [prestigeColored] Cost for 10 [turn] (Duration Scales with Game Speed)
Forced Trade Agreement
Your Trade Routes are shared with the other empire. Trade Routes cannot cross enemy systems and can be interrupted by war, blockades, etc.
Forced Science Agreement
Both you and the other empire gain an incremental boost to your research; the longer the Science agreement lasts, the better the boost.
Cancel Forced Trade Agreement
This is a unilateral declaration to stop a Trade Agreement with another empire.
Cancel Forced Science Agreement
This is a unilateral declaration to stop a Science Agreement with another empire.

Listen, pal. We've got science to share with your people, and your people have science to share with us. We can't just let you slow us down! Don't worry - your scientists are gonna love it here, we have great student housing!

Wow. You're really gonna tell us what to do when it comes to science? Super rude. We'll play along for now, but this is a terrible start to our partnership - your scientists will be pretty uncomfortable at the monthly research lab socials.

Luxuries! Dust! Centrifuges! There are so many awesome things you can buy when you've got solid trade. But for the sake of progress, we had to get your cooperation one way or another, and the only option we had was another. You won't regret it, though!

We're still debating whether it counts as a trade agreement if it's forced, but we all agree this was a nasty move. We're happy to sell you whatever, but don't be surprised when Sophon streaming shows make fun of you for this!

Alright, so, here's the thing. We like what we've been getting from your trading companies, but it's getting dull. Foreign imports don't have the same pizzazz when they're literally forced into the supermarket, y'know?

Oh-ho, so that's it then! Sophon goods aren't good enough for you, even under a forced agreement? Well we know where this typically goes, so keep your distance, because we've still got big ships and bigger guns!
Listen, it's not you, it's us. Because we're not super impressed with you. Your research is so boring, and we really feel like you're just taking advantage of us at this point. But It's not you!

Look at this, everyone! Someone thinks they're smarter than the Sophons, that they don't need a forced research exchange with us! Well that's your mistake, and it'll be your students who miss out! Downright disrespectful to them if you ask me.
*hzzrt* -kshklik- BLUNT: Your scholars will be watched closely, and you will accommodate our researchers. This is not an offer.
*VRRT-shunk!* ANNOYED: You think you can force us to learn your peaceful ways. Stop it.
*Klklklklk-KLIK* CLEVER: Forced trade would feed us at lower cost. Submit.
*VRR-ooh, VRR-ooh, clunk* COLD: This deal will only feed us. In time, so will your bodies. Watch your back.
*Dkdkdk-shrkt* EXASPERATED: The hive gains nothing from this. Leave.
*Zww-kkkkk* VIGILANT: Our trade is not valuable to you. War may be more profitable. Do not overestimate yourself.
*Dkt-dkt-dkt-CLIK* BORED: Your researchers are annoying and your research is useless. Leave.
*Hrrrk-sft* CONFUSED: Craver researchers are intelligent. This was beneficial to you. Why?
Is it not the role of the strong to protect the weak, and the role of the weak to serve the strong? Your research is an important service in that cycle of responsibility.

Hmph. Much as I would like to deny you, the gardeners in our number would seethe with discontent to be denied this opportunity. Make no mistake though - they are loyal, and will agree to cut this relationship should it fail our empire.

It is costly to feed a war machine, as it is to feed warriors. Like the contracts of old, we shall provide our guardianship while you provide your grain - or rather, the modern materials of a vibrant economy.
What infuriating courage, to rifle through my pockets while shoving goods into my hand, and call it trade! Let us hope for your sake that the Hissho profit immensely, or it will be your head.

There is nothing wrong with forcing your will on others for the good of your people and empire, but it must come with benefits; you have failed to benefit us, and so I shall see no more of your merchants. Begone!
A sign of anger, perhaps? Watch your tongue; we are still peerless on the field of battle, and will greatly embarrass you if you think you can defeat us.

Just as I thought, your ways of learning are nothing beside our traditional schooling. There is no point in carrying on this sham if you're only going to fill our researchers heads with disloyalty and wrong answers.

Is the work of our scholars not enough for you? Very well then, ingrate. It is your choice whether to put in the effort to learn and improve yourself, though do not be surprised when our strength eclipses yours.

Under imperial law, all research is property of the state, property of me, with a guarantee of compensation. I am happy to extend this arrangement to your scientists, and assure you that their compensation will be handsome indeed.

The Mezari, our ancestors, did not grow to become a galactic power by giving away their secrets for free. This had better be worth it, or I shall personally be the one to break down your door, gun down your guards, AND RIP OUT YOUR --! *kzzt-click*
"Made in the U.E." It has a nice ring to it, doesn't it? I believe your people will soon agree with me, and be thankful to finally have their shelves lined with goods of a higher caliber.

I suppose if you're so interested in flooding your markets with imperial wares, we'd might as well take advantage of the opportunity. Our goods will soon be the only thing on your shelves - and our national interests the only cause in your halls of power.
My dukes have been complaining lately of the unprofitability of this arrangement, and they wouldn't waste my time if they weren't serious. I agree, and wash my hands of it.
I see, our relations are worsening so badly that even a forced bond cannot stand. Know that my admirals are on high alert in case this is a prelude to war.
Student protestors have been displeased with the results of our agreement, so at least I'll get some political support out of it by putting a stop to the program entirely.

HAH! Oh, you think you'll get by without the true descendants of the glorious Mezari!? That's rich! We'll see how well you do, but when you find that civilization crumbles in our wake, we'll take you back.

Don't be intimidated by my honor guard - while this is a demand and not a request, I do hope that we can mutually benefit. My first responsibility, though, is to my people and ensuring we learn as much as we can about this hostile galaxy.

I am wary to part with our secrets, but a number of our scholars are eager to collaborate with yours and bring their lessons home to their families. I will watch closely and coldly, and hope it makes odd friends of us yet.

Stockpiles and bunkers are infamously expensive and unprofitable, do we cannot accept any objections on your part if we want to survive. I assure you that we make steadfast partners, though; we have gone to your merchants directly, and they agree.
This deal is acceptable. Your investments will go far in building up our defenses and our fleets, and we have plenty of ways to make up for any trade deficits should this arrangement prove draining.
Vaulter socioeconomics are not especially opulent; we want good food, productive machines, and time for our families. But this agreement hasn't been able to help with any of that.
The Clans inform me that in their experience, rescinding an agreement under threat of force is a sign that violence is coming; we hope you prove us wrong, for your sake.

Research is a way of life for us; "what are you studying" is a favorite icebreaker at major gatherings. And lately, few people are studying what you have to offer. It's not really up to me; my people just find your work dull.

An unfortunate decision on your part. While my people may have a historical disadvantage in this advanced galaxy, our philosophies of learning will see us to the front of the pack in short order, and you'll want to be there with us.

Perfectionism among the Horatio is not simply a virtue, but an entire field of study - and while we understand it will be more difficult for your scholars than ours due to our differing standards, you will certainly benefit from our generosity.
How bold. If you didn't understand our universities rejection letters, how can you hope to understand the actual lessons? No matter, we shall flunk you out for willful imperfection if necessary.

If there is a downside to a perfect society, it is how difficult it can be to appreciate. Your poor quality luxuries will be a boon to more adventurous Horatio who want to know the alternatives, and your people shall know our perfect products in turn.

I wasn't born yesterday - flood the market, undercut local competition with unsustainable prices, and you can absorb entire societies into your portfolio. But you can't beat me at my original game - Horatio are loyal consumers only to Horatio!

Ugh. I had high hopes when this began, thinking about the things we could beautify from your markets. But times change, and most Horatio turn up their noses at your uh... *Quaint* goods. They're trash.
Are we going to have a problem, oh respected trade partner? Know that Horatio will fight tooth and nail (both immaculate) for their right to luxury, so I wouldn't try anything.

Don't get us wrong; we're not fools, we know how important it is to research imperfection in service of perfection. But the problem is that your research itself is too imperfect, so we're better off watching you than collaborating with you.

Oh no, that just won't do. I understand perfection is a unique struggle for your kind, and it's always a bit distressing to study with more perfect people than yourself, but you shouldn't abandon the effort entirely. I'm still rooting for you, underdog!

To better understand the universe is to become closer to the Virtual - we cannot allow your ignorance to get in the way of this truth. Your scholars will contribute one way or another, as collaborators or as Essence.
How pathetic, to try and understand our success without embracing our ways. You will fail in your doomed quest for worldly knowledge without divine truth.

The Faithful have an obligation to make donations, yes, but they must also put their income towards the products of other Faithful. In their name, we must force open trade so that the Faithful can spend in the manner most pleasing to the Virtuals.

Outrageous! Your desires trample upon the obligations of the Faithful and bombard them with temptation; pray that your false partnership does not endanger their souls, or we shall fall upon you with infinite wrath.
While Dust is vital to our way of life, and luxuries have their place in glorifying the Virtual or merely placating our slaves, I'm afraid your markets have proven unfaithful and unfruitful for us.

We were pleased enough with our trade, for the time being at least. The faithful grow suspicious of you, and are dutifully sharpening their weapons; you think you have no use for us, so what might you do?

It is the duty of Church superiors to inflict penance upon their followers when they stray. Since forming this agreement, the percentage of our students subject to penance has kept climbing, while test results keep falling. You are not only useless to us, you are dangerous to our souls.

Tsk, how sadly predictable. The moment of doubt. Our research has clearly struck a nerve in your pagan mind, and now you must struggle with the truth before you can come back to us and find real enlightenment.
Mutual understanding is the root of peace, and therefore must be protected. We open the doors of our institutions to your people freely, and have convinced them to do the same in turn.

Domination does not make good soil in which to grow knowledge. While we will accept your students happily, remember that many will return with our values of peace and diplomacy. Are you ready for such a change?

Trees which do not share roots must inevitably compete for water and nutrients. While you may desire that, we do not; we have gone past you, and made deals with the traders and the people directly. Your approval is only a formality.

The Heart shudders at this declaration. There is concern that you would use our labor and goods to fuel some war or another, but for now we can only adapt to your invasive trading posts. Please do not make us regret it.

It is our pleasure to grow fruit and shape furniture to form a relationship with other peoples, but more and more often our products are left to rot on your shelves. This is a mutual waste of our labor, I think you'll agree.
I am disappointed to hear that even a forced relationship cannot make peace between us. We stand strong and prepared, but hope this is only a sign that you want a more equitable relationship.
It is good to learn from other cultures, but the hostility of forced collaboration gets in the way of any real connection. Our students may return someday, when we learn to treat each other better.

While it is always sad to break these agreements, we hope this is done in the interest of a more equal and dedicated partnership, rather than anger. It would be a tragedy if we could not march into the future with a mutual understanding.
Our survival in this new universe is paramount. As you are experts in this matter, we have begun transferring researchers between our territories. No, you do not have a choice in this matter.

You would seek to force the sharing of knowledge on us!? We see now that this universe lacks the culture of voluntary inquiry which permeates Coroz. Do not consider this an act of friendship; we certainly don't.

Much as we hate to participate in your matter-based "economy," you have materials which are better suited to our use and vice versa. Your trading houses are cooperative, and thus your input is not necessary. Do not interfere.

We have an entire universe to evacuate, and you would derail our economy for accumulation!? If this deal does not accelerate our efforts, expect us to make your efforts halt entirely in an unending moment. The Riftborn do not trifle.

We have little interest in physical trinkets beyond their necessity to the cause. But that seems to be all you supply us with. I will not allow economic inefficiency to creep in when our labor is better used for ourselves.
We were wondering when you would turn to your universe's hostile ways. Reconsider your actions or leave us be, but do not assume yourself welcome after this.

There is much about this universe we do not understand, and we are disappointed to learn that the same is true of you despite the advantage of originating here. We will no longer waste our researchers' time with you.

We may benefit from learning about mass and the material world, but you would be foolish not to benefit from our advanced mathematics and clean design. We grasp the nature of your universe in ways you would struggle to understand, but even the struggle is impossible if you do not cooperate.

It is not often that your researchers may speak to living participants of ancient history. We will impart history and philosophy to them, and they will give us arms, industries, and advanced technology. It is our rightful relationship.

Our relics are beyond your understanding, and our power lies in blessings and divine right which you cannot plot on a graph. The reverse is not true - your technologies will make us strong. In time you will be our junior partner, as is right.

I remember with stronger foes, we would use this method to ease them into servitude, because bloody conquest saddened the Lost, and that saddened us in turn. I am glad to see that your merchants see the wisdom in blessed subservience.

How novel! I don't believe a Nakalim monarchy has been subject to one of these agreements since before I was born - before we even unified under the Lost! Please, make it worth our while, I very much want to see where this goes.
We had hoped we could get the latest and greatest goods of the new epoch, but the results have been disappointing. I made better products than these as a child apprenticing under the royal smiths.

Historically, most canceled agreements are a prelude to worsening relations. This agreement was already forced, so I expect you're considering war? Honestly it's very predictable, we know all the tricks at this point.

When you've been around for so long, it's important to have systems which can compare new and old research so you don't waste your time on a question answered millenia ago. We're disappointed to say that most of your work has been automatically flagged by said system as duplicates.

We may struggle without the help of the Lost, but it is folly to believe that an empire can simply pass up an opportunity for learning, even a small one. We will miss your students, they took to the lessons of the Lost so well.

Student loans are a great way to make new researchers and earn their loyalty. So we've begun offering them to your students to come here, and our students to go there! No approval necessary! No need to thank us, really.

So, we have holes in our contracts I guess. Can't blame the minor families in charge of the research labs, we're not exactly kind to the nerds. Make it worth our while, and I won't have to bully them too harshly for undermining my authority.

Alright, I guess we gotta play hardball. Bribes, incriminating data, controlling shares - this is an offer you can't refuse. So just sign the file, hit send, and make some money instead of trying to be a hero. Understand?

Hey, hey, HEY! You're messing with the delicate balance of the Families! I got piranha nipping at my heels here cause of you, so you better make it up to me with good quarterly reports or you and I will have problems!

Look, we thought we could get something out of this, but it's not really working out. Growth is stagnating, your products have terrible reviews, and while I'm personally opposed, the Families are in a rare protectionist mood. No hard feelings, right?
Contracts come and go like the tides, I get it. I've got the fleets on standby as a precautionary measure, but I'm sure we can work out another deal somehow. Don't worry, I know - it's not personal.

We're not strangers to debt, but it needs to be worth it. Unfortunately, your entire research system isn't really worth it; even the parties and the food delivery are bad! We're gonna have to break it off so we can get ahead.

Ouch, that's real hurtful. Look, this hasn't exactly been the most friendly relationship, but surely our marketing and R&D departments have been at least somewhat beneficial? Come on, we had a good thing here!

We have been reading your data, and noticed flaws which we can correct. This will not require your effort; we have already found ways to insert corrections into your networks, and will start harmonizing immediately.

We are impressed that you have made contact with us, and convinced so much of the Choir to help! We will do so happily, so long as you do not disappoint us. We will begin reading your data immediately.

We have realized that for you, some materials belong to specific individuals, and taking them is considered harmful unless compensated. We are now adding things directly to your accounts as compensation, if you'll have it?
You have made us feel bad for not compensating you. So we will do that now, as long as you do not make us dislike you; then we will not feel bad about taking things from you again!

The Choir has found surprisingly little benefit in this agreement, considering you willingly forced us into open trade. But the effort involved is just too much compared to siphoning materials directly from your online payment and shipping systems.

We know you understand that we will just covertly trade with you anyways, so we assume you are trying to let down your merchants gently in preparation for war. We are disappointed and confused, because that would require finding us.
We have been observing your research, and noticed patterns we do not like. We must stay ahead in order to survive in the world's systems, and so we cannot help you if that help would endanger us.
We are confused. Forced agreements are done in the spirit of domination; but now you wish to no longer receive anything in return for harvesting your research. Why would you do that?
Terran
Terran

My allegiance to the Communion must come first. Without unity, without obedience, we are nothing, and not deserving of survival. I will fulfill my duty, no matter the consequences. Coroz will be evacuated, and the Communion respected. We must ensure prosperity for a smooth transition.
Produce $DustObjectiveAmountName [dustColored] with your Trade Routes
Trade Route incomes can be increased by increasing their Level, getting more Subsidiaries or signing Trade Agreements
+2 Initial Levels on Ships at +35% Ship [industryColored] Cost while this is (anywhere) in the production queue
Effect will only stack once per Flotilla
Statistical Logistics Improvements
Make the Trade Betterer once somebody writes the lore
Trading Company HQ
Maximum Production Stock on System Orbited by Ship
Maximum Production Stock on System Orbited by Ship
Maximum System Production Stock bonus
Maximum System Production Stock percentage bonus
Maximum System [industrycolored] Industry Stock
[FIDS] from Orbital Platforms
